MICROSCOPIC:   (Dr. X. Armour)
Sections show disseminated undifferentiated spindle cell malignant tumour comprising of cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm including scattered multinucleated forms. The tumour is seen to involve mesentery, wall and submucosa of segments of small bowel and colon. In addition, there are deposits of tumour in separately submitted peritoneal fragments.

Immunoperoxidase staining of the tumour cells shows patchy positive staining with Cam5.2 and AE1/AE3 with no staining for calretinin, HBME-1, EMA, WT-1, CD5/6, D-240, S100 or Pax-8.  Strong staiing with p53 is seen. Very weak staining for oestrogen receptor is seen with no staining for progesterone receptor.

Comment:  The appearances are those of undifferentiated spindle cell malignant tumour.  In view of the previous history of sarcomatoid ovarian carcinoma the current recurrence is most likely a sarcomatoid carcinoma.

- DISSEMINATED SPINDLE CELL MALIGNANT TUMOUR IN KEEPING WITH SARCOMATOID CARCINOMA (SEE COMMENT).

HISTOPATHOLOGY REPORT:
HISTORY:
Peritonectomy.  Left femoral artery lymph node.  Peritoneal stripping. Bowel specimen.
Previous:
SEALS report 76M276233 from 26/1/2065, peritoneal disease resection and appendiceal tumour.

MACROSCOPIC:
A.  &quot;COLON PERITONEAL STRIPPING WOUND&quot;. Consists of two segments of bowel and multiple pices of fibrofatty tissue.  The first segment of bowel measures 160mm in length with a maximum diameter of 30mm. The attached mesocolic fat is up to 45mm wide.  One margin is inked blue, the other black. The surface is roughened with areas of adhesion.  On opening the mucosa shows flattened mucosa.  No discrete mass lesion is identified.
(1 margins; 2 section through roughened serosa; 3 one possible node from mesocolic fat)
The second segment of bowel measures 110mm in length with a maximum diameter of 30mm.  The serosa is roughened with areas of adhesion. The mucosa is flattened with some mild nodularity.  One margin is inked blue, the other black.  Within the attached mesocolic fat is mucinous tumour deposit. (4 margins; 5 two section, one showing serosal mucinous deposit and area of nodularity within mucosa; 6 mucinous deposit within mesentery; 7-9 one lymph node each bisected) The separate pieces of fibrofatty tissue in aggregate measures 260x190x30mm within which are mucinous tumour deposit.  (10-13 RS showing mucinous tumour deposit [11 tumour block]).  RS (M-13)

B.  &quot;LEFT FEMORAL ARTERY LYMPH NODE&quot;. Consists of a nodule of fatty tissue. It measures 20x10x8mm.  Bisected. AE (2-1/MC 30/10/2067 ank)

MICROSCOPIC:   S Knick

A. The previous reports are noted. The sections show disseminated peritoneal involvement by low grade appendiceal mucinous neoplasm (LAMN), AJCC grade 1, consensus classification: low grade mucinous carcinoma peritonei (DPAM disseminated peritoneal adenomucinosis).

The mucinous neoplasm deposits involve the surface of bowel and fatty ?omental tissue and other tissues. The deposits are of low cellularity with many areas consisting of organising acellular mucin and in other areas there is associated neoplastic epithelium, small quantities, arranged in thin monolayers, with low grade nuclear features. There is no invasion identified.  Sampled lymph nodes are negative for tumour.  There is no signet ring carcinoma or high grade component identified.

B.  The lymph node shows reactive changes.

DIAGNOSIS:
A. PERITONECTOMY SPECIMEN - peritoneal deposits of low grade appendiceal mucinous neoplasm (LAMN), AJCC grade 1, consensus classification: low grade mucinous carcinoma peritonei (DPAM disseminated peritoneal adenomucinosis).

B.  LEFT FEMORAL ARTERY LYMPH - lymph node, negative for tumour.

A.  &quot;RIGHT OVARY AND TUBE&quot;.  A fallopian tube 45x15mm with attached part of ovary 25x20x10mm with unremarkable outer and cut surface.  Received also multiple fragments of ovary measuring 50x45x25mm in aggregate.  The fragments are of smooth outer surface and solid firm white areas.  Cystic corpus luteum is identified within the fragments measuring 24mm in maximum diameter.

(1-3 tube [1 fimbrial end two LS, 2&amp;3 tube with adjacent part of ovary]; 4- 11 ovary [4 smaller fragments, 5 corpus luteum, 6-9 smaller fragments serially sliced, 10&amp;11 largest fragment with solid area serially sliced]).  AE (M-11).

B.  &quot;LEFT OVARY AND TUBE&quot;.  A fallopian tube 35x5mm with unremarkable outer and cut surface.  Received also multiple fragments of ovary 2-25mm, 70x40x15mm in aggregate.  The cut surface reveals solid friable areas with minute papillary excrescences.

MICROSCOPIC:   (Dr V Lucario)
A.  Histology shows evidence of a high grade serous carcinoma arising within the fimbria of the right fallopian tube adjacent to which foci of serous tubal intraepithelial carcinoma are present.  There is stromal invasion with desmoplasia and high grade cytological atypia, frequent mitoses with an occasional focus of tumour necrosis.  Deposits of serous carcinoma are also seen within the right ovary.  Immunostains show positivity for WT1, P16, PAX8, ER(60% 2+), PR (40% 2-3+), CK7. P53 is completely negative. Ki67 is approximately 80%.

B.  Histology shows much of the left ovary to be infiltrated by high grade serous carcinoma with identical morphology to that described above.  The left fallopian tube does not appear to be involved.

C.  Histology shows fibrofatty tissue with a small focus of metastatic high grade serous carcinoma.

D.  Histology shows most of the specimen to consist of mucus with occasional strips of endocervical and squamous epithelium.  No endometrial tissue is present.  This is a non-diagnostic specimen.

DIAGNOSIS:
A.  RIGHT OVARY AND TUBE -  HIGH GRADE SEROUS CARCINOMA OF RIGHT FALLOPIAN TUBE INVOLVING THE RIGHT OVARY

B.  LEFT OVARY AND TUBE -
- HIGH GRADE SEROUS CARCINOMA INVOLVING LEFT OVARY

C.  POUCH OF DOUGLAS -
- SMALL FOCUS OF METASTATIC HIGH GRADE SEROUS CARCINOMA

D.  ENDOMETRIAL CURETTINGS -  NON-DIAGNOSTIC

HISTORY:

Small bowel / colon + abdominal wall.

MACROSCOPIC:
&quot;SMALL BOWEL, COLON, ABDOMINAL WALL&quot;.  Received an en bloc specimen segment of large bowel 220x60 mm  with anastomosis line to a segment of small bowel 210x40mm. There  are attached disrupted mesocolon and mesentery adherent to central specimen up to 60mm in length adjacent to a segment of skeletal muscle (abdominal wall) 70x35x15mm. Possible fatty tissue consistent with omentum is adherent measuring 100x75x20mm.

There is confluent involvement of the serosal surfaces of large bowel, small bowel mesentery by firm white tumour  which  disseminate along the serosal surface of the specimen and extensively invades into the adjacent fat, the bowel wall to abut the underlying mucosal surface of small and large bowel. Mesenteric lymph node are macroscopically involved and replaced by tumor deposits. There is tumor invasion into the abdominal wall segment and the submitted possible omentum. The tumor is difficult to delineate but the maximum tumor diameter is 160 mm. The tumor deposits are clear of the longitunal and radial resection margins. No polyps or intraluminal bowel tumours are identified.  The abdominal wall resection margin is inked black.

(1 proximal and distal resection margins; 2&amp;3 continuous slice abdominal wall involvement; 4&amp;5 continuous slice serosal nodule with small bowel involvement; 6 large bowel involvement; 7 tumour tracking the peritoneal surfaces with adjacent bowel wall [tumour block for tissue banking]; 8 tumour into fat ?omentum; 9&amp;10 each four lymph nodes within mesentery).  RS (M-10/ZH 23/11/2067 nh)

MICROSCOPIC:   (Dr B Sears)
The sections show tumour present within fibrofatty soft tissues including mesentery/mesocolon of the bowel.  The tumour broadly infiltrates into both small and large bowel into the muscularis propria and also into submucosa and in the small bowel segment there is also infiltration into the lamina propria.  Broad areas of necrosis are identified.  The tumour shows variable morphology including glandular-tubular structures and some more solid of growth of epithelioid cells as well as some areas with a tendency towards spindling of malignant tumour cells.  Many mitotic figures are seen.  There is eosinophilic cytoplasm and with nuclear pleomorphism including vesicular chromatin and nucleoli.  The tumour is not seen to infiltrate into the adherent skeletal muscle of the anterior abdominal wall in the section examined.  Tumour is present in six lymph nodes.
The morphological appearances are those of a biphasic epithelioid and spindling tumour with cytologic pleomorphism.  These appearances are consistent with the given history of mesothelioma.
DIAGNOSIS:
SMALL AND LARGE BOWEL AND ABDOMINAL WALL - MESOTHELIOMA.

The uterus and cervix measures 105x60x55mm.  The cervix measures up to 50mm from right to left with a 10mm slit like os. The right fallopian tube measures 50mm and is up to 10mm in width. The right ovary is 28x25x12mm.  The left fallopian tube measures 52mm in  length and up to 10mm in width.  The left ovary measures 30x20x10mm.  The endometrium measures up to 2mm in thickness and the myometrium up to 25mm in thickness maximally posteriorly. There is a IUCD in situ.

Right hemicolectomy specimen consisting of terminal ileum stump measuring 30x20mm, caecum 30x50mm, and ascending 80mm in length and up to 50mm in open circumference. There is pericolic fat up to 50mm in thickness with adherent mucinous disease.  The appendix is not identified. (1 anterior cervix; 2 posterior cervix; 3 posterior endomyometrium; 4 anterior endomyometrium with overlying mucinous tumour; 5 right parametrium; 6 right ovary with underlying cyst and overlying mucinous disease; 7 right fallopian tube with mucinous disease; 8 left ovary; 9 left fallopian tube; 10 mucinous disease of peritoneum attached to uterus; 11 sampled section of gallbladder; 12 sampled section of spleen; 13 terminal ileum and ascending colon margins; 14 caecum and ascending colon; 15 pericolic fat; 16&amp;17 sampled peritoneum; 18-20 sampled omentum).  RS (M-20/MY 12/7/2067 ank)

MICROSCOPIC:   (Dr P Woester)
Sections of the cervix are unremarkable.  The endometrium shows decidual reaction and inactive to weakly secretory patterned glands.  The myometrium is unremarkable.  On the serosal surface of the uterus and in the right parametrium there are extracellular mucus deposits and in the right parametrium these are associated with strips and groups of columnar mucinous epithelium, some of which show stratification.  Similar deposits of extracellular mucus are seen on the surface of the right and left ovaries and the right and left fallopian tube serosa.  In several areas, there is multilayering  with occasional apoptotic and mitotic figures and with a tendency towards vesicular chromatin with small nucleoli.  In other areas, there is a more bland appearing mucinous epithelium with abundant apical cytoplasm and basally located nuclei.  Similar mucinous deposits with mucinous epithelium are seen on the peritoneal reflections adjacent to the uterus.
The section of the gallbladder shows deposits of extracellular mucus with associated mucinous epithelium on its serosal surface.
The section of the spleen shows normal appearing splenic parenchyma, and with deposits of mucus associated with columnar mucinous epithelium on the serosal surface.
Sections from the segments of colon and small bowel show unremarkable appearing mucosa and submucosa and serosa.  Sections from the caecum and ascending colon show a hyperplastic-type polyp.
Sections of the pericolic fat show serosal deposits of extracellular mucus associated with strips and glands of columnar mucinous epithelium.
Sections of the separate fragments of peritoneum and omentum show deposits of extracelluular mucus associated with strips and glands of columnar mucinous epithelium.  In some areas, there is multilayering and with vesicular chromatin with irregular nuclei, with single or multiple small nucleoli.  Some apoptotic figures are also seen.
Comments:  There are numerous deposits of extracellular mucus associated with columnar mucinous epithelium with a predomianant low grade nuclear cytology with focal intermediate grade features. This is overall considered low grade in this material (PSOGI nomeclature - low grade mucinous carcinoma peritonei). Correlation with previous pathology results is recommended.

DIAGNOSIS:
PERITONECTOMY SPECIMEN: -
- LOW GRADE MUCINOUS CARCINOMA PERITONEI - SEE TEXT AND COMMENTS

HISTORY:
G II endometrial adeno ca.

2.  Uterus, tubes and ovaries.
3.  Omental biopsy.
4.  Right pelvic sentinel node.
5.  Left pelvic sentinel node.

MACROSCOPIC:
A.  &quot;UTERUS, TUBES AND OVARIES&quot;.  An already coronally opened total hysterectomy specimen of a total weight of 90g.  The uterus measures 75x50x40mm.  Attached is a right fallopian tube 45x5mm, right ovary 17x10x8mm.  A left fallopian tube 45x5mm and left ovary 15x10x10mm.  The external os is oval 10x10mm with surrounding unremarkable ectocervix.

Occupying the fundus and the left posterior body, a partially polypoid and partially endophytic lesion measuring 27x24mm.  Including the exophytic component, the tumour is of a total thickness of 20mm out of 37 mm and possibly focally invading less than one half of the underlying myometrium (up to 19mm thick in uninvolved areas).  The tumour is confined to the uterus focally approaching the left cornu and is located 50mm of the cervical  distal resection margin, 20mm of the nearest left parametrial margin.

The remainder endometrium is up to 3mm thick.  The remainder myometrium is unremarkable.  The outer cut surface, both ovaries and tubes are unremarkable.

(1  right tube three LS fimbrial end and one TS mid; 2  LS right ovary; 3  shave right parametrial margin; 4  left tube two LS fimbrial end and one TS mid; 5  LS left ovary; 6  shave left parametrial margin;
7-13 sections from anterior uterus:
[7-9  LS uterus from cervix to fundus; 10&amp;11  LS tumor at body and fundus with loose part of tumour in slice 11; 12  LS tumour at body; 13  coronal section left cornu;]
14-19 sections from posterior uterus;
[14-16  LS uterus from cervix to fundus; 17&amp;18  each one LS body; 19  coronal section left cornu ] ).  RS (M-19).  Please refer to diagram.

Further blocks of cervix and endocervical canal were taken.  (20&amp;21  anterior right endocervical canal; 22-29  left endocervical canal from midline to left side [22&amp;23  one LS, 24&amp;25  one LS, 26&amp;27  one LS, 28&amp;29  one LS]; 30-33  left posterior cervix and endocervical canal [30&amp;31  one LS lateral]; 32&amp;33 one LS medial; 34&amp;35  posterior right cervix and endocervical canal).  Please refer to diagram.  RS (M-35/ZH 19/1/2067 km).

B.  &quot;OMENTUM&quot;.  A fibrofatty piece of tissue 9x6x3mm.  AE (1-1).

C.  &quot;RIGHT PELVIC SENTINEL NODE&quot;.  A fibrofatty piece of tissue measuring 20x20x5mm bearing three lymph nodes measuring 3mm, 5mm and the largest measures 18x9x4mm with fatty firm tan and brown cut surface.

(1  two smaller lymph nodes; 2&amp;3  larger lymph nodes serially sliced).  AE (M-3).

D.  &quot;LEFT PELVIC SENTINEL NODE&quot;.  Multiple fibrofatty pieces of tissue, 25x20x10mm.  Six possible lymph nodes are identified measuring 3mm to 9mm in maximum diameter.

(1  smaller two lymph nodes and remainder fat; 2  largest lymph node trisected; 3-5  each one lymph node bisected).  AE (M-5/ZH 16/1/2067 km).

MICROSCOPIC:   (Dr R Fried)
A. Sections of the macroscopically described polypoid and endophytic endometrial lesion show FIGO Grade 2 endometrioid endometrial adenocarcinoma. The adenocarcinoma involves the outer half of the myometrium, 8mm of a total depth of myometrium of 12mm. There is focal lymphovascular invasion. In addition, there is a tumour deposit in the deep myometrium (A18) which is discontinuous from the invasive tumour front, and less than 0.5mm from the serosal surface. The deposit most likely arose in a focus of lymphatic spread, and has not been incorporated into the depth of invasion measurement.

The endometrial carcinoma is multifocal. A deposit of tumour in the lower uterine segment extends into the endocervical canal where there is glandular and stromal involvement. This involvement is prominent in the region of a lower uterine segment scar with foreign body suture granulomas, presumed site of LSCS. In the vicinity of the scar, the endometrial adenocarcinoma involves 3mm of the total depth of cervical wall of 6mm. Away from the scar, the maximum depth of involvement is 3mm add to a total of 14mm. The endometrial adenocarcinoma and the cervical involvement show similar immunoprofile for ER, CEA, p16 and Vimentin, and there is no identifiable cervical AIS or high-grade squamous dysplasia.The ectocervix is unremarkable. Bilateral parametrial tissue, ovaries and fallopian tubes are unremarkable. See synoptic report.

MICROSCOPIC:   S Krey
Sections of the peritoneal mucin disease show peritoneal deposits of low grade mucinous neoplasm in this setting consistent with appendix origin (peritoneal deposits of LAMN). The deposits consist of dissecting mucin with low cellularity and include strips of mucinous epithelium arranged in monolayers with low grade atypia and occasional small clusters and single cells. Some of the mucin peritoneal deposits are rounded with a fibrous capsule and a peritoneal covering.  Many of the deposits have associated granulation tissue and some fibrosis and these are macroscopically firm. Signet ring cells are not seen.

RECTUM, OLD STOMA, PERITONEAL DISEASE -

AMENDED REPORT FOR TYPOGRAPHIC ERROR (13/12/67)

CLINICAL:
Right back muscle lesion ?recurrent liposarcoma.  Left pelvic lesion ?recurrent liposarcoma.  Previous right retroperitoneal liposarcoma 2063.


MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right back muscle tumour ?sarcoma stitched superior&quot;, consists of fibroadipose tissue and muscle, 83 x 48 x 55mm, with an overlying ellipse of skin, 85 x 20mm.  There is a suture within the soft tissue marking superior, which will arbitrarily be taken as 12 o&apos;clock.  The skin surface is unremarkable.  The superior/12 o&apos;clock margin is inked blue and the inferior/6 o&apos;clock margin is inked black.  The specimen is sectioned transversely from 3 o&apos;clock to 9 o&apos;clock into thirteen slices.  Within skeletal muscle, there is a firm, pale grey tumour in slices six to twelve, 40 x 25 x 23mm.  The tumour is 1mm from both the superior/12 o&apos;clock and the deep margin (meeting point between blue and black ink).
Blocks: 1 - LS slice one (3 o&apos;clock); 2 - deep aspect slice six; 3 - deep aspect slice seven; 4 to 8 - slice eight; 9 to 13 - slice nine; 14 - deep aspect slice ten; 15 - deep aspect slice eleven; 16 - deep aspect slice twelve; 17 &amp; 18 - LS slice thirteen (9 o&apos;clock).  Complete visible tumour embedded.  Please refer to block diagram.

B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Recurrent liposarcoma left pelvis&quot;, consists of a non-oriented, nodular, pale grey tumour, 52 x 48 x 34mm.  The outer surface is inked blue.  On sectioning, the tumour has a solid, relatively uniform, fibromyxoid appearance.  No areas of necrosis are identified.  RS 6 blocks.  (Block 6 - reserve block).  (TO:JB/rs 1/11/67)

Slides received CA 7/12/67.


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr H Fenimore):
A. Sections show a high grade spindle cell sarcoma largely located within skeletal muscle. The majority of the lesion is encapsulated, and is composed of atypical, spindle shaped tumour cells with pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei forming intersecting short fascicles. Scattered giant cells with bizarre nuclei are present. There are 60 mitoses per 10 hpf, including atypical forms. Areas of hyalinisation are present in the centre of the lesion. No convincing coagulative necrosis is identified.

FNCLCC grade: 3 (6 out of 8)
Tumour differentiation: 3 (morphologically undifferentiated sarcoma)
Necrosis: 0
Mitoses: 3 (&gt; 20/10 hpf)

Immunohistochemistry:
To follow.

Margins:
Deep: focal +ve over a 0.7mm front
Inferior: 5mm
Superior: 7mm
Medial: 10mm
Other margins: &gt; 15mm

Comment: The features are of a high grade spindle cell sarcoma. While no well differentiated liposarcoma is seen, given the previous history of dedifferentiated liposarcoma, the features would be consistent with high-grade dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

B. Sections show high-grade dedifferentiated liposarcoma. A capsule of variable thickness and extensive hyalinisation are seen.  Much of the lesion resembles high grade undifferentiated sarcoma, similar to specimen A. Up to 21 mitoses are present per hpf. In addition there are less cellular areas characterised by scattered tumour cells with pleomorphic nuclei located within myxoid stroma. Tumour cells with nuclei indented by cytoplasmic vacuoles are seen, suggestive of lipoblastic differentiation (B2). No necrosis is identified.

High-grade tumour is &lt; 0.1mm from the margin in several sections.


DIAGNOSIS:
A. Right back muscle tumour:
- 40mm high-grade spindle cell sarcoma, consistent with high-grade dedifferentiated liposarcoma
- Confirmatory immunohistochemistry to follow

B. Left pelvis recurrent tumour: 52mm high-grade dedifferentiated liposarcoma


ADDITIONAL REPORT (8/12/67)
A. The tumour cells are negative for EMA, Melan A, myogenin, panCK, SMA and SOX10. Positive staining is seen for vimentin. Non-specific focal weak staining is seen for S100 and desmin. Vimentin is positive. Ki67 index is approximately 15%.

The diagnosis is unchanged.


AMENDED REPORT FOR TYPOGRAPHIC ERROR (13/12/67)
The diagnosis for specimen A should read &quot;high-grade spindle cell sarcoma&quot; not &quot;high-grade spindle cell carcinoma&quot;.

This has been amended above.

CLINICAL:
Liposarcoma retroperitoneum from diaphragm to scrotum on left.  Resected with bowel and left kidney.  Suture on renal pedicle.  Left hemiscrotectomy as separate specimen.
Specimen is oriented by Dr J Signorile.


MACROSCOPIC:
A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Left retroperitoneal mass plus left kidney, adrenal and colon&quot;, consists of
a composite specimen weighing 4,950g.  The specimen measures 360mm (superior to inferior) x 220mm (medial to lateral) x up to 180mm (superficial to deep).  A segment of bowel is on the anterior aspect and measures 170mm long and the kidney with attached adrenal gland is identified posteriorly and measures 110 x 60 x 55mm in total.

An anterior mass of tumour (clinically ?dedifferentiated) measures 210 x 150 x 90mm.   The nodule is removed from the remainder of the specimen.  On sectioning, the anterior nodule has a multilobulated fatty appearance compromising approximately 40% necrosis.  Tumour extends to all margins.

A 45mm solid nodule is identified arising within the mesentery of the attached bowel segment, separate from the main fatty posterior mass.  This nodule has discrete lobulated fatty cut surface with a peripheral rim of calcification and cystic change.

In the region near the ?inguinal canal there is a 25mm firm nodule abutting the deep margin.

The posterior mass otherwise has a multilobulated fatty appearance with no discrete areas of haemorrhage, necrosis or solid change.   Several possible lymph nodes are identified in a deep chain corresponding to position of aorta.

Inking Key
The anterior nodule is inked:
Anterior = blue, posterior = purple, medial = red and lateral = green.
The remaining posterior mass is inked:
Anterior = blue, posterior = black, medial = red, lateral = green, kidney hilum = yellow, ?inguinal canal attachment = yellow, residual tissue around detached anterior nodule = purple.

Blocks: 1 to 14 - anterior nodule (1 and 2 - superior; 3 and 4 - anterior; 5 and 6 - medial; 7 and 8 - lateral; 9 and 10 - posterior; 11 and 12 - inferior; 13 and 14 - central tumour); 15 - renal hilar vessels; 16 - hilar lymph nodes; 17 - possible ureteric margin; 18 - proximal and distal bowel margins; 19 - shave of ?inguinal canal; 20 and 21 - superior adrenal and kidney with adjacent superior fat; 22 - renal hilum with hilar fat (medial); 23 - inferior kidney with adjacent perinephric fat/tumour; 24 to 26 - composite section through 45mm mesenteric nodule; 27 to 36 - posterior mass (27 and 28 - anterior margin; 29 and 30 - posterior/deep margin; 31 and 32 - medial margin; 33 and 34 - lateral margin; 35 and 36 - inferior margin); 37 - tumour with adjacent bowel wall; 38 - RS through 25mm ?inguinal canal nodule; 39 - one possible node; 40 - one node bisected; 41 - tumour for biobanking; 42 to 45 - remainder of nodule seen in 38;  46 - fibrous septae embedded en face; 47 to 51 - further RS of mottled fat ?mosaic type; 52 - tissue inferior to block 23. See blocking diagram.

B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Left scrotal mass&quot;, consists of a scrotal mass, weighing 475g and measuring 170 x 85 x 70mm.  The skin ellipse measures 100 x 65mm.  On sectioning the cut surface demonstrates a multilobulated fatty tumour extending from the spermatic cord into the scrotal cavity and abutting the testis.  Individual tumour nodules measure up to 60mm in maximum dimension and have a variable haemorrhagic and mucoid cut surface.  No definite necrosis is seen.  No solid areas are identified.  The testis (35mm) is still confined within the tunica albuginea.  The tunical sac is dilated by serous fluid.  The fatty tumour extends to the peripheral and deep margins, and separated only by a thin fibrous layer.  Please note, fibrous layer retracts during fixation and sectioning.

Inking Key:
Deep = black, medial = red, lateral = blue.

Blocks:  1 - TS shave spermatic cord margin/edge; 2 to 5 - composite section through spermatic cord superior to skin; 6 - superior skin with underlying tumour; 7 - deep margin with dense fatty nodule; 8 - medial skin and tumour; 9 - medial margin; 10 - deep margin; 11 - lateral margin; 12 - lateral skin with underlying tumour; 13 - further lateral margin; 14 - central tumour; 15 - tumour with adjacent testis; 16 - inferior margin with testis.  See blocking diagram.     (TO:AP/hh 19/8/69)


MICROSCOPIC: (Reported by Dr J Zippe &amp; Dr J Springman)
A.  Sections of the 360mm abdominal mass show a liposarcoma.  The tumour has large anterior and posterior macroscopic components. Overall, the tumour is predominantly a well differentiated liposarcoma with a lesser component of dedifferentiated liposarcoma (mosaic pattern). The well differentiated liposarcomatous component includes lipoma-like, sclerosing and inflammatory subtypes, and consists of lobules of atypical adipose tissue with variation in adipocyte size, conspicuous nuclear enlargement and hyperchromasia, scattered lipoblasts and variably prominent fibrous septae. The foci of dedifferentiated liposarcoma (mosaic type pattern) appear largely confined to the posterior component, and consists of expansile foci of undifferentiated high grade sarcoma admixed within areas of well differentiated liposarcoma.

Anterior component:
The 210mm anterior nodule consists predominantly of lipoma-like liposarcoma with large areas of tumour necrosis.

Margins of excision (anterior component): The well differentiated liposarcoma extends broadly to all surgical margins.

Posterior component:
The 360mm posterior nodule consists predominantly of well differentiated liposarcoma (lipoma like, sclerosing and inflammatory types) with scattered admixed foci of dedifferentiated liposarcoma (mosaic pattern). Well differentiated liposarcoma abuts the renal capsule, infiltrates the subserosa of the attached bowel to abut the muscularis propria and interdigitates between, and encases, lymph nodes along the bed of the medial aorta. The parenchyma of the included colon, kidney, ureter and adrenal gland appear otherwise involved.
There is also a discrete 45mm mesenteric focus of organising fat necrosis with a calcified capsule containing foreign body type giant cells. There are scattered foci of dedifferentiated liposarcoma (mosaic pattern) consisting of discrete, infiltrative and expansile sclerotic nodules containing moderately cellular sheets of malignant pleomorphic, hyperchromatic sarcomatoid tumour cells and scattered islands of entrapped well differentiated liposarcoma. These individual foci represent a small component of this large liposarcoma (A23 and A28), with each individual focus up to 10mm, and arising in areas where there is an increased component of sclerosing type liposarcoma (A46 to A51).

Eight lymph nodes are identified (adjacent to the medial aortic bed at the posterior aspect), one of which shows extensive effacement by dedifferentiated liposarcoma (with areas of meningothelial-like whorls and variably sclerotic stroma). This is favoured to represent a metastatic deposit (1/8). At least two of the sample nodes also show direct involvement by well differentiated liposarcoma characterised by replacement of hilar adipose tissue by lipoma like liposarcoma.

Margins of excision (posterior component):
Well differentiated liposarcoma: extends broadly to all surgical margins.
Dedifferentiated liposarcoma (mosaic pattern):
- Posterior margin: Less than 0.1mm (A45) (nodal deposit).
- Lateral margin: 3.3mm (A34).
- Anterior margin: 5.5mm (A28).
- Medial margin, superior and inferior margin: clear of dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

B.  Sections of the 170mm scrotal mass show a well differentiated liposarcoma. The tumour has a predominantly lipoma-like morphology, as well as, a lesser component of sclerosing-type, and surrounds and encases the testis. Other areas show variable myxoid stroma and cystic change.  A discrete 25mm nodule shows increased cellularity and greater cytologic atypia, including prominent floret-like giant cells, consistent with a focus of dedifferentiated liposarcoma (pleomorphic liposarcoma-like morphology). The liposarcoma tumour spares the overlying skin, separated from the dermocutaneous tissue by skeletal fibres of the detrusor muscle. The testis shows active spermatogenesis.

Margins of excision:
Well differentiated liposarcoma extends to the spermatic cord margin and broadly to peripheral (medial, lateral, superficial and deep) margins and is greater than 5mm from the inferior margin (in proximity to testis).

Dedifferented liposarcoma (pleomorphic liposarcoma like): Less than 0.1mm from the deep margin; less than 1mm from lateral margin; clear of remaining margins (&gt;10mm).


DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Left retroperitoneal mass: Well differentiated liposarcoma (present broadly at margins) with focal dedifferentiation (mosaic pattern), less than 0.1mm to posterior margin.

B.  Left scrotal mass: 170mm Well differentiated liposarcoma (present broadly at margins) with 25mm focus of dedifferentiated liposarcoma (less than 0.1mm from deep and 1mm from lateral margins).

Histology shows deposits of metastatic signet ring cell adenocarcinoma found throughout the omentum with infiltration of the serosa of the small bowel where there is extension through muscularis propria into submucosa, and similarly, with infiltration with the surface of the muscularis propria of the colon. No malignancy is seen in 11 local mesenteric lymph nodes. Within the uterus, there is widespread infiltration infiltration of the stroma of the cervix and the myometrium. There is widespread lymphatic vascular invasion in the myometrium with the tumour displaying a more solid/ acinar pattern of differentiation.There is also focal serosal involvement of the gall bladder and within the deep fibrous tissue deep to the skin of the umbilicus. Immunostains on the omental deposits show positivity for CK7, CK20, CDX2 with patchy retention of neuroendocrine markers suggesting that the current lesion may have originated from a prior goblet cell carcinoid of appendiceal origin.

MICROSCOPIC:   (Dr Q Nevels)
A. These show pale eosinophilic cytoplasm with atypical nuclei including nucleoli. The ovary shows a densely fibrotic background stroma. Lymphatic space invasion is identified. The fallopian tube surface epithelium appears unremarkable.
Sections of the ectocervix appear unremarkable. Within the endocervical canal and lower uterine segment, there is infiltrating tumour with similar appearances to that seen in the ovaries and fallopian tubes. The tumour involves the endometrial and endocervical mucosa with infiltration into the cervical stroma and into the myometrium. In addition, subserosal deposits of carcinoma including lymphatic space invasion are identified.

Her-2: Negative (0 staining).
B. The sections show fragments of omental adipose tissue with fibrosis and with single cells, small groups of cells and ductal-tubular spaces with atypical nuclear features and with some cells showing intracytoplasmic vacuoles.
Comment: The appearances are those of metastatic adenocarcinoma consistent with invasive duct carcinoma of breast.
DIAGNOSIS:
A. UTERUS, OVARIES AND FALLOPIAN TUBES
- METASTATIC INVASIVE DUCT CARCINOMA.

B. OMENTUM

HISTOPATHOLOGY REPORT:
HISTORY:
Middle of appendix, base of the appendix, extended right hemicolectomy, appendix, omentum.  Discussed with Prof Antilla, mass in cardia or stomach - probable primary lesion.  Previous lap bx of peritoneum suggestive upper GIT primary.
MACROSCOPIC:
A.  &quot;MIDDLE OF APPENDIX&quot;.  Pale firm tissue 7x3 with serosal fat 8x5x3mm. (1  frozen section).  AE (1-1)
Frozen section: &apos;Poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma infiltrating appendix from the outside.  Normal mucosa&quot;.  Results to Prof H Godzik, report by Dr H Dermott.
B.  &quot;BASE OF APPENDIX&quot;.  Pale tissue 8x5x3mm with attached fat 8x6x5.  Pale tissue bisected. AE (2-1).
Frozen section: &apos;Poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma infiltrating appendix from the outside.  Normal mucosa&apos;.  Results to Prof Graner, reported Dr  H Willet.
C.  &quot;APPENDIX&quot;.  A previously partially opened appendix measuring up to 65mm in length up to 7mm in width with attached ragged mesoappendix up to 7mm.  There appears to be a haemorrhagic fibrinopurulent exudate involving the serosal surface.  Specimen all embedded blocks C1 to C5 tip to base.  AE (M-5).
D.  &quot;RIGHT COLON&quot;.  An extended right hemicolectomy specimen.  Specimen consists of small bowel at least 315mm in length and open circumference of up to 40mm.  There is attached mesentery up to 25mm in thickness.  There is a pale exudate over the mesenteric surface of the small bowel and patchy haemorrhagic dusky areas of the small bowel serosa.  The mucosal surface of the small bowel is unremarkable.  There is large bowel up to 290mm in length with an open circumference ranging from 60 up to 120mm.  The caecum measures up to 40mm in length and up to 50mm in width.  The appendix stump is identified.  There is pericolic fat up to 30mm in thickness.  The serosal colon surface of which has multiple tumour deposits as well as patchy haemorrhagic areas.  There is a firm attached omental  cake involving the distal 180mm of the colon.  The caecal and ascending colon mucosa is slightly flattened where dilated but is otherwise unremarkable.  There is a separate piece of fatty tissue measuring 85x65x15mm.  One surface is smooth and fatty.  The other is smooth with patchy haemorrhagic areas. (1  proximal resection margin [small bowel]; 2  distal resection margin transverse colon; 3, 4, 5&amp;6  are sampled sections of small bowel mesentery including small bowel mucosa and possible nodes; 7  caecum serosal nodule; 8-13  omental cake; 14  firm nodule Tx transverse colon; 15  peritoneal nodule).  RS (M-15/MY km).

MICROSCOPIC:   H Osorio
Previous results  (22B03130 RIF peritoneal disease biopsies, from 30/1/2067 are noted)
Current specimens:

A.  MIDDLE OF APPENDIX
Sections show bowel wall with mucosa ?appendix and full thickness muscularis propria with adjacent mesenteric fat.  The mesenteric fat and muscularis propria and very focally submucosa is involved by metastatic carcinoma.  The mucosa is unremarkable.

B.  BASE OF APPENDIX
The sections show part of bowel wall ?appendix with external involvement by metastatic carcinoma.

C.  APPENDIX
Sections of the previously opened appendix show involvement by metastatic carcinoma involving mesoappendix fat and muscularis propria and extending very focally into submucosa.  The remaining unopened ?proximal appendix is normal.
There is no evidence of an appendix primary.

D.  RIGHT COLON
The peritoneal surface of the small bowel mesentery and the peritoneal surface of the colon, and the omental cake show extensive involvement by metastatic carcinoma.

The tumour is of variable appearance with single cells, small clusters, some areas with limited extracellular mucin and some cells with intracytoplasmic mucin vacuoles. In some areas of non-mucinous growth (B13) the tumour cells have high grade nuclear atypia and there are numerous mitoses present in these areas (&gt; 10 mitoses/single high power field). In many areas the tumour cells are dyscohesive. There is no evidence of a neuroendocrine component or goblet cell carcinoid component.

Sampled lymph node (mesenteric) are negative for tumour (0/5).
Lymphovascular invasion is not seen.

Immunostains:
Block D14, mesocolic peritoneal tumour:
ecadherin negative
ER negative
CEA, keratin CK7: positive
See also Immunostains on previous biopsy, most not repeated

Intracytoplasmic mucin vacuoles are present in some cells.

COMMENT
The carcinoma in each of the above specimens is metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma (G3) discohesive cell type with occasional intracytoplasmic mucin vacuoles. The appearances favour origin from stomach in the proper clinical setting, but clinical correlation is required to assess organ of origin.

DIAGNOSIS:
A-D.  APPENDIX BIOPSIES, APPENDIX, RIGHT COLON AND OTHER ORGANS -
- extensive peritoneal deposits of metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma (G3), dyscohesive type, favour stomach origin in proper clinical setting, see COMMENT.
- invasion into muscular wall of submitted organs but appearances favour invasion from peritoneal surface rather than origin from appendix, colon or small bowel.

Theaxillary tail contains a 70mm mass of matted lymph nodes showing extensive involvement by metastatic adenocarcinoma. The mass of matted nodes contains foci of tumour associated necrosis and carcinoma extends to the inked margins in areas.
C.  Sections show fibroadipose tissue containing a 16mm focus of metastatic adenocarcinoma. At least two partially involved nodes are identified (2/2), however, tumour replaces much of the tissue. There is focal perineural invasion. Scattered large calibre vessels are present.
D.  Sections of the lateral left axillary lymph node show metastatic adenocarcinoma with extranodal extension of 0.56mm.
E.  Sections of the leftapical node show metastatic adenocarcinoma with extranodal extension of at least 5.5mm.
F.  Sections show a benign endometrial polyp. There are no atypical features. There is no evidence of malignancy.
DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Right breast tissue plus axillary dissection:
3.3mm grade 3 invasive carcinoma of no special type.
Multifocal lymphovascular space invasion and focal perineural growth.
Metastatic carcinoma in 9 of 12 lymph nodes (largest nodeup to 16mm in dimension with extranodal extension up to 1.6mm).
ER positive; PR and Her-2 negative.
Metastatic carcinoma in 9 of 12 axillary lymph nodes (9/12).

B.  Left breast tissue and axillarydissection:
110mm grade 3 invasive carcinoma of no special type.
The carcinoma shows extensive involvement of breast tissue, including focal nipple epithelium and subareolar stromal involvement.
Lymphovascular space and perineural invasion present.
ER positive; PR and Her-2 negative.
70mm depositof metastatic tumour in axilla within mass of matted lymph nodes.

C.  Node left axilla above axillary vein: Metastatic carcinoma involving at least two lymph nodes infiltrating fibroadipose tissue(2/2). Focal perineural invasion.

D.  Lateral left axillary lymph node: Metastatic adenocarcinoma withextranodal extension of at least 0.56mm.

E.  Left apical node: Metastatic adenocarcinoma with extranodal extension of at least 5.5mm.

F.  Curettings: Benign endometrial polyp.

HER-2 SISH is beingperformed at Molecular Oncology BRIDGETOWN HOSPITAL and separate reports will be issued.

HISTOPATHOLOGY REPORT:

HISTORY:
Left pararectal mass, right pararectal mass, pelvic mass, pelvic tumour x 2, right pelvic side wall.

MACROSCOPIC:
A.  &quot;RIGHT PARARECTAL MASS&quot;. A fibrofatty piece of tissue measures 70x35x15mm with possible glistening surface (peritoneal covering) is identified on one area (inked blue). The remainder surface is inked black.  The specimen is serially sliced into 12 slices.  The cut surface reveals area of thickening with ill defined lesion towards the possible peritoneal surface in slices 5-7. The remainder cut surface is fatty and unremarkable.

(1 LS slice 1 and 12 [peripheral edges]; 2 firm area slice 4; 3 firm area slice 5; 4 slice 6; 5 slice 7). RS (M-5)

B.  &quot;LEFT PARARECTAL MASS&quot;.  Multiple fibrofatty pieces of tissue consistent with fat with overlying covering peritoneum measuring 110x65x20mm in aggregate. The serosal surfaces are extensively ragged and haemorrhagic with firm and fibrous cut surface.  The possible margin is inked blue.

(1-4 RS firm areas).  RS (M-4)

C.  &quot;PELVIC MASS&quot;.  Three tissue fragments and appendix 53x5mm with unremarkable outer and cut surface. A fibrofatty piece of tissue measures 55x25x6mm with unremarkable outer and cut surface and a firm hard mass measures 90x60x37mm with a disrupted overlying smooth capsule. The margins are inked blue.  The mass is serially sliced into 16 slices. The cut surface reveals mainly solid tan and haemorrhagic lesion becomes cystic towards one end with spaces filled with clear serous fluid.  The mass appears to be encapsulated in most of the lesion with edges abutting the margin macroscopically.

(1 appendix base; 2 appendix tip [all appendix embedded]; 3 two LS RS fibrofatty tissue; 4 onwards mass [4 two LS slice 1 [detached tumour capsule], 5&amp;6 slice 2, 7-10 slice 8, 11 slice 11; 12 cystic edges of the lesion in slice 14 and 16]). RS (M-12)

D.  &quot;PELVIC TUMOUR&quot;. One solid piece of tissue 8x4x5mm. The margins are inked blue. Bisected. AE (2-1)

E.  &quot;PELVIC TUMOUR 2&quot;.  A fibrofatty piece of tissue measures 35x30x25mm with a disrupted partial mass with smooth inner lining, haemorrhagic and tan centre measuring 20x20x15mm.  The haemorrhagic mass is disrupted and appears to be partially cystic at one edge.

(1&amp;2 TS across the specimen with mass; 3&amp;4 mass towards the cystic end).  RS (M-4)

F.  &quot;RIGHT PELVIC SIDE WALL&quot;. A fibrofatty piece of tissue 16x10x5mm.  It has a glistening surface (? peritoneum).  The remainder margins are inked blue. The cut surface is firm solid and brown across the specimen.  AE (5-1/ZH 16/2/2067 ank)

MICROSCOPIC:   (Dr Y Kunstlinger)
A,C,D&amp;E. Sections show involvement of all of these specimens by metastatic well differentiated neuroendocrine tumour. The tumour is characterised by closely arranged lobules with foci of pseudoacinar architecture. There is patchy mild to moderate nuclear atypia and a brisk mitotic grade (25 mitoses/10hpf). There are also foci of necrosis. The tumour focally forms a surgical margin of Specimen A (right pararectal mass), and forms the surgical margins of Specimen C,D&amp;E (pelvic mass, pelvic tumour and pelvic tumour No. 2) over a broad front in the specimen.

Immunohistochemical stains performed on block C5 show positive staining of the tumour for CAM 5.2, chromogrannin A, synaptophysin, CD56 and PAX8 and negative staining for TTF1 and CDX2. The proliferative index (Ki67) is 25%.
The appearances and immunoprofile are those of grade 3 (WHO) well differentiated neuro-endocrine tumour as previously documented (95Q10357, 95Q103572C, 24/9/65).

Specimen C also includes the appendix which shows a sessile serrated adenoma and mild periappendicitis.

B. Sections show strips of peritoneum with florid reactive mesothelial hyperplasia and mixed inflammation. There is no evidence of malignancy.

F. Sections show unremarkable fibroadipose tissue. There is no evidence of malignancy.

DIAGNOSIS:
A. RIGHT PARARECTAL MASS
- METASTATIC WELL DIFFERENTIATED NEUROENDOCRINE TUMOUR.

B. LEFT PARARECTAL MASS
- FLORID REACTIVE MESOTHELIAL HYPERPLASIA, ACTIVE INFLAMMATION.

C. PELVIC MASS
- METASTATIC WELL DIFFERENTIATED NEUROENDOCRINE TUMOUR.

D. PELVIC TUMOUR
- METASTATIC WELL DIFFERENTIATED NEUROENDOCRINE TUMOUR.

E. PELVIC TUMOUR NO. 2
- METASTATIC WELL DIFFERENTIATED NEUROENDOCRINE TUMOUR.

F. RIGHT PELVIC SIDE WALL
- BENIGN FIBROADIPOSE TISSUE.

24&amp;25 splenic involvement; 26 left colon disease;

33&amp;34 RS).  RS (M-34/ZH 17/2/2067 nh)

Sections show disseminated epithelioid malignant mesothelioma with tubulopapillary architecture with transmural involvement of stomach and serosal and muscularis propria involvement of segments of small bowel, terminal ileum, caecum and appendix, transverse colon and rectosigmoid.

Epithelioid malignant mesothelioma is also seen involving the capsule of the liver with focal extension into liver parenchyma, splenic capsule, serosa of gallbladder and separately submitted peritoneal fragments, omentum and possibly diaphragmatic fragments.

Lymphovascular invasion by the mesothelioma is seen.  No sarcomatoid component is identified.

SMALL BOWEL, DIAPHRAGM, COLON, SPLEEN, STOMACH, PERITONEAL DISEASE,
- DISSEMINATED EPITHELIOID MALIGNANT MESOTHELIOMA.

MACROSCOPIC:
&quot;KRUKENBERG, DISTAL STOMACH, OMENTUM&quot;. A distal gastrectomy specimen consists of lesser curve, 60mm; greater curve, 130mm; and is up to 105mm in circumference with attached soft tissue at the lesser curve, up to 20mm; and greater curve, up to 15mm. Also received within the same specimen jar, is a fibrofatty piece of tissue consistent with omentum, 220x115x15mm; two grossly enlarged ovaries, 75x50x45mm, and 70x65x45mm; and a fibrofatty piece of tissue with covering peritoneum, 60x25x15mm.

The stomach has been opened across its greater curve. The cut surface reveals diffuse thickening of the stomach centrally over an area measuring 60x40mm which has cental  ulceration 15x10 mm. HISTOPATHOLOGY REPORT:
SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT 24/3/68

HISTORY:
Liposarcoma.

MACROSCOPIC:
&quot;RETROPERITONEAL LIPOSARCOMA&quot;.   Received fresh.
Post fixation assessment: A soft tissue mass 570x500x180 mm weighing 9152 grams. The anterior surface is lobulated and smooth with an adherent segment of large bowel 120 x 40mm. The posterior surface is ragged and includes a kidney 120x65x35 mm with attached ureter 140x4mm and adrenal gland 40x20x15 mm. The mass comprise lobules of firm yellow tumor with variable cut surface including white and firm areas, myxoid areas and bright yellow areas. There are also focal pearl like hard areas (? cartilaginous).  Tumor necrosis is present and comprises 25% of the cut surface. The tumour invades into renal sinus fat which has a pale cut surface and pushes the renal pelvis. It also invades into the adipose tissue adjacent to the adrenal gland. The fat lobules show pushing invasion of the the large bowel wall with no definite intraluminal involvement. The anterior surface is inked blue the posterior resection margin is inked black.

Received separately a right hemicolectomy specimen consisting of terminal ileum 60mm, caecum and ascending colon 80mm with attached mesentry and mesocolon up to 50mm. The appendix is unremarkable 75x8 mm. The serosal surface is unremarkable. No polyps or tumors are identified. Focal bulky mesenteric fat lobule is seen with unremarkable cut surface.

There is a separate length of small bowel 170mm in length and up to 25mm in width with  stapled margins.  The serosal surface is unremarkable.  There is mesentery up to 15mm in thickness attached.  The opened mucosal surface is unremarkable.

(1-6  initial blocks representative tumour; 7 tumour for tissue banking)(ZH 24/2/2067 km). Post fixations blocks ( 8 kidney resection margins; 9 kidney at hilum; 10 tumor pushing renal pelvis; 11 tumor into kidney parenchyma; 12 tumor with adrenal gland; 13-17 posterior resection margin; 18&amp;19 ? cartilage area within tumor- no margins; 20 anterior adherent large bowel resection margins (prox and distal); 21-25 tumor with anterior resection margin; 26 thick white tumor area- no margin; 27 right hemicolectomy resection margin; 28 bulky mesentery with caecal wall) RS (M-28/ZH/2.1.67).

Further blocks:
(29&amp;30 appendix [29 tip and one TS, 30 base and one TS]; 31-33 RS left small bowel [31 one resection margin, 32 other resection margin, 33 RS). RS (M-33/MY 2/2/2067 nh)

MICROSCOPIC:   (Dr Q Malatesta)
Sections confirm the clinical diagnosis of liposarcoma.  The tumour has been extensively sampled, and the morphology varies from areas of well differentiated (lipoma-like) liposarcoma to areas of high grade sarcoma. These well differentiated and high grade areas are often intimately admixed. The morphology of the high grade areas varies from myxoid areas with admixed highly atypical often multinucleated stromal cells resembling high grade myxofibrosarcoma. Other areas are characterised by more fibrous to frankly sclerotic stoma containing numerous markedly atypical multinucleated cells with scattered mitotic acitviity (1 per 10hpf) and multi-vacoulated cytoplasm. Some of these multinucleated cells resemble floret cells (pleomorphic liposarcoma-like). Others have appearances suggestive of rhabdoid/myogenic differentiation (possible heterologous differentiation). There are areas of tumour necrosis.  A panel of immunostains show that the lipoblasts are positive for S100, and the pleomorphic cells in the de-differentiated components are positive for desmin.  Smooth muscle actin and CD34 highlight the vascular component of the tumour and cytokeratin Cam 5.2 is negative.

In most of the sections, the tumour is characterised by a circumscribed un-encapsulated edge.  Anteriorly, tumour abuts the peritoneal (mesothelial) surface as well forms the anterior non-peritonealized surgical margin with no intervening normal tissue.  Tumour also forms the posterior surgical margin in a number of sections with no intervening normal tissue.  The tumour focally infiltrates the outer muscularis propria of the encased segment of large bowel, but does not infiltrate mucosa or submucosa, and the mucosal resection margins of this segment are not involved.  The liposarcoma also partially encases the kidney without renal parenchymal involvement.

Sections of the kidney show very occasional sclerotic glomeruli and small hyalinised renal tubular foci suggestive of chronic pyelonephritis.  Sections of the renal pelvis and ureter are unremarkable. Sections of the ureteric and vascular kidney resection margins are unremarkable.

Sections of the appendix show fibrosis of the lumen at its tip. Sections of the small and large bowel resection margins from the right hemicolectomy component are unremarkable. Sections of the separately received length of small bowel show foci of serosal inflammation, but no evidence of malignancy.

Comment: In this site, an adipocytic tumour with well and poorly differentiated areas almost certainly represents a de-differentiated liposarcoma. Sections will be referred for MDM2 and CDK4 ISH and a further report will follow.

DIAGNOSIS:
RETROPERITONEAL TUMOUR -
-  LIPOSARCOMA WITH BOTH WELL DEDIFFERENTIATED AND POORLY DIFFERENTIATED COMPONENTS, FAVOUR DE-DIFFERENTIATED LIPOSARCOMA.
- TUMOUR FOCALLY ENCASES A SEGMENT OF LARGE BOWEL AND THE ANTERIOR ASPECT OF THE KIDNEY.
-  CIRCUMSCRIBED UNENCAPSULATED TUMOUR MARGIN FORMING ANTERIOR AND POSTERIOR SURGICAL MARGINS
- ISH AND FURTHER REPORT TO FOLLOW.

3/5/2068 nh

SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT 24/3/68
Please see separate report for MDM2 and CDK4 FISH both reported as &quot;amplification DETECTED&quot;. This finding supports the favoured diagnosis of DE-DIFFERENTIATED LIPOSARCOMA.

MICROSCOPIC:   (Dr V Crace)
Sections show a poorly circumscribed deposit of high grade sarcoma within skeletal muscle. There is extensive central tumour necrosis. The rim of viable tumour is composed of atypical oval to spindled cells arranged in haphazardly orientated fascicles. There is moderate nuclear atypia and brisk mitotic activity.
Immunostains show that the tumour is weakly positive for smooth muscle actin and negative for desmin and S100. The proliferative index is approximately 50% (Ki67).
The tumour is surrounded on all aspects by a rim of benign tissue. The smallest margin (0.2mm) is at the 9 o&apos;clock peripheral margin (assuming that skeletal muscle forms the anterior aspect of the specimen).

Comment: The appearances and immunoprofile are consistent with recurrent leiomyosarcoma. The previously reported leiomyosarcoma was negative for SMA and desmin in the poorly differentiated areas (85A64811, 85A6481114, 2/5/66).

DIAGNOSIS:
ORIENTATED EXCISION LESION ANTERIOR ABDOMINAL WALL - RECURRENT SARCOMA, CONSISTENT WITH POORLY DIFFERENTIATED LEIOMYOSARCOMA, FOR MARGINS, SEE TEXT.

A.  Sections show a serous carcinoma involving serosa and parametrium of uterus, both ovaries and fallopian tubes.  The tumourshows predominately psammomatous calcification (more than 95%).  Focally, neoplastic serous epithelium is present (less than 5%) with mild cytological atypia and papillary architecture.  Tumour cells with high grade nuclei are also focally seen.  Within the tumour, there is extensive fibrosis and numerous foamy macrophages.  In the right clinical setting the appearances are in keeping with those of previous neoadjuvant therapy.  The uterus shows a large intramural leiomyoma.  There is a large endometrial polyp with cystically dilated gland.  The rest of endometrium is atrophic.  The cervix is unremarkable.  For both ovaries, the tumour mainly involves the surface and outer halves of cortex.  The lumen of right fallopian tube is completely filled by tumour.  In the specimen A, the tumour appears to be centred on right fallopian tube and right ovary.

D.  Sections show omental tissue involved by a serous carcinoma with extensive psammomatous calcification (more than 95%).  The appearances are identical those described in the specimen A.
Comment:
The tumour shows extensive psammomatous calcification (more than 95%).  It is difficult to properly grade the tumour due to minimal amount of neoplastic epithelium (less than 5%).  The presence of extensive fibrosis and numerous macrophages is suggestive of previous neoadjuvant therapy.  If the patient had received neoadjuvant therapy, please refer to previous biopsy for tumour grading.  The most likely primary site is peritoneum.  The right fallopian tube is another possibility.  Clinical correlation is needed.  The case is shown to Dr K Byker and Dr BRYAN HALLIMAN.

A.  Uterus, tubes and ovaries &#8211; Serous carcinoma.Leiomyoma.  Endometrial polyp.

Proximal surgical margin inked green, distal inked black and circumferential margin inked blue.  Thickness of mesorectum 35mm. Possible anterior uterus surface inked blue, posterior inked black.  Uterus opened sagittally.  Endometrium measures 1mm, anterior wall 11 and posterior 11mm. (10-12  one full face sagittal of the uterus [10  includes cervix]; 13&amp;14  section of uterus and deposit; 15  section of adnexal area).

Spleen weighs 165 and measures 110x60x70mm with portion of fat 60x40x30mm attached.  Foci of thickening present over the serosa.  There is no parenchymal involvement identified.  Representative section embedded block 16 and 17.

MICROSCOPIC:  (Dr. T. Dahlgren)
A.  The uterine ectocervix is focally present and is unremarkable.  The endocervix shows some nabothian cysts.  The endometrium is atrophic.  The myometrium shows benign leiomyomas.  The surface of the uterus shows a thick layer of highly atypical mesothelial cells arranged in sheets, trabeculae and pseudoglandular formations.  They show pleomorphic nuclei, occasional nucleoli, coarse chromatin and moderate amounts of pale eosinophilic cytoplasm with occasional mitoses.  They focally invade into the very outer layer of the myometrium.  There is also  invasion into the peritoneal reflection which is attached to the uterine specimen.

There are nodules of similar highly atypical epithelioid mesothelial cells present on the serosa of the colorectal specimen.

The spleen shows a nodule of similar atypical mesothelial cells on the surface.

The gallbladder shows features of chronic cholecystitis.  There is a focus of similar highly atypical mesothelial proliferation in the serosal fat

The omental fragments are widely infiltrated by similar highly atypical epithelioid mesothelial cells.

Immunohistochemistry shows positive staining of the atypical cells for calretinin, CK5/6, D2-40, HBME-1, cytokeratins CAM5.2 and AE1/AE3, and some cells are positive for EMA.  There is negative staining for CEA, CDX2 and BerEP4.

The features are of a highly atypical mesothelial proliferation, consistent with the history of metastatic malignant mesothelioma.

B.  The liver shows a circumscribed nodule composed of hepatocytes arranged around a central stellate scar with some bile ductular proliferation.  Hepatocytes show clear vacuolated cytoplasm, different to the surrounding more normal-appearing liver.  There is some mild macrovesicular steatosis.  There is no mesothelial malignancy.  Special stains are being performed and further characterisation of the liver nodule will follow in a supplementary report.

DIAGNOSIS:
A.  ANTERIOR RESECTION, UTERUS, GALLBLADDER, OMENTUM, SPLEEN, PERITONEAL DISEASE:
- MALIGNANT MESOTHELIOMA PRESENT ON THE SEROSA OF THE LARGE BOWEL, SURFACE OF THE UTERUS, SURFACE OF THE SPLEEN, SEROSA OF THE GALLBLADDER AND EXTENSIVELY INVOLVING THE OMENTUM.

B.  LIVER LESION SEGMENT 1:
- NO MESOTHELIAL MALIGNANCY.
- FURTHER CHARACTERISATION OF HEPATOCYTE NODULE TO FOLLOW

B.  The circumscribed nodule shows features of focal nodular hyperplasia. There is some iron pigment present within Kupffer cells, absent in hepatocytes.  There is no malignancy.

Near the resection margin is a cystic structure measuring 30 x 30 x 25mm with an intact and smooth outer surface.  The pancreas weighs 94g.  The cystic structure appears intact.  Stapled line is removed with the residual margin inked black.  The inferior splenic vessel impression is identified.  Anterior surface inked blue, posterior red, and superior green.  On sectioning the lesion at the head of the pancreas is filled with thin, mucoid and clear fluid and is unilocular.  The proximal 45mm of the pancreas is sectioned longitudinally with the remaining pancreatic tissue sectioned transversely.  The cystic structure has a capsule less than 1mm in thickness throughout with a smooth internal surface.  The proximal longitudinally sliced section is sliced into 7 slices, with the remaining distal pancreas serially sliced TS into slices 8 to 23.  Please refer to attached photograph for specimen.  Additionally within the specimen container is a piece of omentum measuring 440 x 230 x 60mm.  On sectioning no definitive lymph nodes are seen.

(TO: MS; MS/rs 18/3/67)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr H Rigney):
The pancreas is entirely embedded and examined.  The 30mm cystic tumour within the pancreas is an intrAduct papillary mucinous neoplasm  (IPMN) with low grade dysplasia.  The tumour is composed of cystically dilated spaces lined by flat or shallow papillary mucinous epithelium of gastric type.  The underlying wall is variably fibrous and no ovarian type stroma is identified. The epithelium is lined by cells with rounded elongated bland nuclei which is predominantly simple with focal pseudostratification and occasional small nucleoli.  Mitoses are not identified.  The tumour appears to expand the main pancreatic duct with extension into some smaller branch ducts (favour combined main duct with involvement of branch ducts).  There are some associated patchy acinar atrophy.  No invasive carcinoma is seen.

SUMMARY PANCREATIC TUMOUR

Histological tumour type:  Intraduct papillary mucinous neoplasm ( gastric type) with low grade dysplasia

Microscopic tumour sites:  Distal pancreas favour main duct with involvement of branch ducts (please correlate with preoperative imaging)

In some areas disruption of the specimen makes assessment difficult.  Where intact the tumour is located as follows.
Anterior:  0.9mm(block 15)
Posterior: 0.6mm (block 6)

Lymph nodes:  Two negative lymph node


DIAGNOSIS:
Subtotal pancreatectomy:
- Intraduct papillary mucinous neoplasm (gastric type) with low grade dysplasia, at least 30mm, , margins clear.

A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Pancreatic biopsy&quot;, consists of six core biopsies measuring 8 to 15mm across as well as three fragments 2 to 3mm.
Blocks: 1 - six cores; 2 - three fragments.  AE 2 blocks.

B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Gallbladder&quot;, consists of a gallbladder, 80 x 30 x 30mm.  The serosa appears smooth and shiny and partially congested.  There is a defect over the fundus 8 x 8mm.  There is no lymph node.  The gallbladder wall is 1 to 4mm in thickness.  The mucosa is green and velvety.  No stone is identified within the gallbladder or jar.  No gross lesion is identified.
Blocks: 1 - cystic duct margin and TS neck; 2 - TS body; 3 - LS fundus including edge of defect.  RS 3 blocks.

C.  Specimen labelled &quot;Omentum&quot;, consists of a segment of omentum, 220 x 160 x 10mm which appears unremarkable.  On sectioning no gross lesion is identified.  Representative 4 blocks.
(TO:LN; LN/ta 22/3/67)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr I Morado):
Sections show cores of tissue including tissue surfaced by duodenal mucosa at one end of the core and gastric type transitional type mucosa at the end of another core.  The gastric mucosa could represent heterotopic mucosa from the duodenum.  The tissue is extensively infiltrated by moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma.  The carcinoma is composed of tubular and cribriform glands as well as some solid nests and cords of cells with moderate and focally highly pleomorphic nuclei, occasional eosinophilic nucleoli and eosinophilic cytoplasm.  There is associated sclerosed desmoplastic stroma.  One of the cores include atrophic pancreatic parenchyma with sparse residual islet cells and lobulocentric atrophic ducts and  contains relatively sparse infiltrating carcinoma.  The tissue surfaced by gastric and small bowel mucosa also contains muscularis which is infiltrated.  The carcinoma involves the duodenal mucosa and focally appears to reach the gastric type mucosa.  There is associated villous atrophy in the duodenal component.  No intraepithelial lymphocytosis is seen.  There is focal perineural invasion. A focus highly suspicious for lymphovascular invasion is also present.
COMMENT:
The morphology of the tumour, although not specific is consistent with a pancreaticobiliary primary.

B.  Sections of gallbladder show chronic cholecystitis.  There is thickening of the gallbladder wall and patchy mild transmural chronic inflammation.  The specimen includes a portion of subcapsular hepatocellular parenchyma which shows canalicular cholestasis, highlighted with a Hall&apos;s stain for bile.  Perls staining shows hepatocellular iron deposition through the lobules with a zone 1 and canalicular accentuation.  The iron deposition is grade 3/4 (Modified Scheuer grade) There is some ductular proliferation within the portal tracts unassociated with oedema or neutrophils, however this is difficult to interpret given the subcapsular nature of the sample.  There is no evidence of malignancy.  No lymph nodes identified.

COMMENT:
The canalicular choestasis presumably relates to intrapancreatic biliary obstruction. The presence of hepatocelluar iron deposition (grade 3/4) warrants further investigation.


C.  Sections show mature adipose tissue.  There is no evidence of malignancy.

DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Pancreatic biopsy:
- Moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma invading duodenum and tissue surfaced by gastric transitional type mucosa (? heterotopic in duodenum or native gastric)
-  Focal perineural invasion
-  Focus highly suspicious for lymphovascular invasion
B.  Gallbladder:
-  Mild chronic cholecystitis
-  Canalicular cholestasis in liver
-  Hepatocellular iron deposition (see comment).
C.  Omentum:
- No evidence of malignancy

The findings were discussed with Dr COLLIN PROVIS on the 25.3.67

A.  Sections show multiple tumour deposits replacing the liver parenchyma with the largest nodule measuring up to 105mm across.  The tumour is composed of malignant cells arranged in nests and trabeculae with occasional pseudoglandular formations.  The tumour cells have abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm with focally bizzare nuclear atypia, vesicular chromatin and large eosinophilic nucleoli.  Abundant mitotic figures are present.  Focal fatty change is seen within the tumour.  The tumour shows positive staining with PanCK, cam5.2, AE1/3, arginase and glypican 3.  There is focal staining with AFP.  Sinusoidal cells are identified with the CD34 stain encircling tumour nodules and a canalicular staining pattern is seen with CD10.  The Hepar-1 stain (repeated) is negative.  In addition the CK7, CK20, CDX2, TTF-1 and SOX-10 stains are negative. The appearance is consistent with moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma.  Some of the tumour nodules show central necrosis and extensive lymphovascular invasion is present.  Many of the tumour nodules stretch the overlying capsule but no capsular penetration is seen.  Tumour abuts the hepatic resection margin after removal of surgical staples however, the true margin is possibly clear.  There is no definite extension of tumour into adherent adipose tissue or within the wall of the gallbladder.  The gallbladder otherwise shows no significant abnormality and the cystic duct lymph node is uninvolved.  The background liver shows a mild non-specific chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate but no other significant abnormality.

B.  The five (5) lymph nodes show no significant abnormality.  There is no evidence of malignancy.


DIAGNOSIS:
A.  Liver:
-  Moderately differentiated multinodular hepatocellular carcinoma
-  Extensive lymphovascular invasion
-  Close surgical resection margin
-  No invasion into attached adipose tissue or gallbladder
-  Benign cystic duct lymph node
B.  Hilar lymph nodes:  Five benign lymph nodes.

Facility_id: 016

Pathology Report

CLINICAL:
Liver metastasis.  R breast Ca, GORD, HTN, hypercholesterolaemia, anxiety disorder, cataracts.  Liver lesion.  Likely gastric or pancreatic primary.


MACROSCOPIC:
Specimen labelled &quot;Liver biopsy&quot;, consists of a liver wedge, 10 x 9 x 6mm with a possible grey nodule, 3mm.  RS for FS.
Blocks: 1 - the frozen section; 2 - the remainder.  AE.
(TO: HM; HM/rs 2/3/67)


FROZEN SECTION REPORT:
Poorly differentiated carcinoma.
Phone results to Dr B Mourino, by Dr B Gandolfo at 2:23pm on 27/1/17.


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr B Venible):
Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show liver extensively infiltrated by a moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma.  The carcinoma is arranged in solid nests as well as occasional glandular structures, the latter highlighted on dPAS staining. The tumour cells display a predominantly monomorphic round to oval nuclei with inconspicuous nucleoli and eosinophilic cytoplasm with some areas of cytoplasmic vacuolation.  In some areas close to the liver capsule the tumour cells appear more squamoid with more abundant cytoplasm, more pleomorphic nuclei and possible occasional intercellular prickles.  No keratinisation is seen.  There is small and medium sized vessel vascular invasion which is highlighted on both CD31 and Orcein stain.

Immunohistochemistry:
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive:  	GATA 3 (diffuse strong), CK7 (diffuse strong), TTF1 (patchy strong), p63 (strong almost diffuse) and CK5/6 (accentuated in squamoid areas).
Negative:	CK20, PAX8, PR, Her2 (1+), Synaptophysin, Chromogranin, CD56, Napsin A
Equivocal:       ER, some minimal patchy possible weak nuclear staining in the context of stronger 				 cytoplasmic staining.

COMMENT:
The features are those of a poorly differentiated carcinoma predominantly adenocarcinoma with some possible squamous differentiation.    In the context of a lesion obstructing the distal stomach this would appear to be the likely primary site, however, the immunoprofile (CK 7 positive, GATA 3 positive, ER essentially negative )  is not informative is separating the possibilities of either breast, gastric or pancreatic origin.The  TTF1 expression is likely aberrant given the clinical history, however, origin from a lung primary  also cannot entirely be excluded.

The morphology is similar to the poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma seen in the previous gastric biopsy, although  that tumour did not show squamoid features.  Although  the tumour in the  gastric biopsy did not show definite associated glandular dysplasia or intestinal metaplasia althe morphology there is entirely compatible with a gastric primary.     In initial large series GATA 3 expression, commonly seen in breast carcinoma,  was rare  (&lt;10%) in gastric adenocarcinoma. However, a recent study reported strong expression in up to 44% of cases of gastric adenocarcinoma. GATA 3 expression may also be seen in pancreatic carcinoma.  Immunostains are performed on the gastric biopsy and the tumour shows the the same expression pattern as the liver metastasis, namely diffuse strong GATA3 and CK7 expression, a similar pattern of ER staining (non-specific cytoplasmic with equivocal weak nuclear) while CK20 is negative. If it is clinically important to exclude the possibility of breast carcinoma comparison with the morphology and hormone receptor status of the previous breast carcinoma  may be useful.  Further correlation with the imaging findings would be of interest.


DIAGNOSIS:
Liver biopsy:
- Metastatic poorly differentiated carcinoma with glandular and possible squamous differentiation.

The cyst contains dark brown fluid and the inner lining is flat.  The cyst wall is generally around 4mm thick but in the thickened area is up to 14mm thick.  The area of thickening measures 50mm x 20mm.
Blocks: 1 to 20 - all of the thickened area including resection margin; 21 - RS of cyst wall; 22 to 25 - cyst wall with serosal fat (TO: LM;LM/vo 5.4.67).  Re-select - 26 to 29 - further sections (NL 8.4.67).


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr E Munkberg):
Sections of the described cyst-like structure show central necrotic debris and a lining of fibrous tissue and multi layered histiocytes, some of which are hemosiderin laden.  The cyst wall consists of fibrous and hyalinised tissue of rather low cellularity but with scattered patchy areas of moderate cellularity.  The cells in the cyst wall have spindle shaped nuclei and generally scant poorly defined cytoplasm and there is an associated mild, patchy infiltrate of histiocytes and other mixed chronic inflammatory cells.  The majority of the spindle cells stain c-kit (CD117) positive. Mitoses are very infrequent in this component.  The features are consistent with a gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST) showing moderate to marked treatment effect.
Numerous sections have been examined and there is a single focus of markedly cellular tumour identified, 3mm diameter (block 20).  In this focus the cells have large atypical nuclei with one or more nucleoli and scant cytoplasm.  In this focus there are numerous mitoses, numbering up to ten per high power field.  This focus is away from excision margins and does not extend to the serosal surface, and stains c-kit positive.
The outer surface of the mass is irregular with some patchy adherent fat.  In many of the sections there is a layer of dense, poorly cellular fibrous tissue between the treated tumour and the adherent fat.  No significant infiltrative growth of tumour into overlying fat is seen.
Sections of the described thickened area show that this is stomach wall with overlying body type mucosa.  The mucosa is essentially unremarkable.  Dense hyalinised fibrous tissue consistent with treated tumour obliterates part of the muscularis propria and extends into submucosa, but the overlying mucosa is intact.
A single small piece of adrenal cortex is noted within fat on the serosal surface of the mass focally (block 9); there is no tumour involvement of the adrenal cortex.
The whole area of attached stomach mucosa and wall has been blocked.  The staples had to be removed prior to sectioning of the tumour so it is difficult to assess the adequacy of excision.  However no definite treated tumour is seen at the resection margins of the adherent stomach wall as far as these can be assessed.


DIAGNOSIS:
Recurrent gastric GIST:  GIST showing moderate to marked treatment effect.  Single small residual focus of cellular mitotically active tumour identified, see text.


SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT (18.4.67):
The proliferation index in the cellular tumour focus with a Ki-67 stain is around 20%.

SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT (24.4.67):

CLINICAL:
Left thigh sarcoma for tissue histopath stitch marked short superior, medium medial, long lateral.


MACROSCOPIC:
Received fresh and tissue banked from deep margin.
Specimen labelled &quot;Short superior long lateral medium medial left thigh sarcoma &quot;, consists of an orientated piece of fibrofatty tissue with an overlying skin ellipse.
The skin ellipse runs superior to inferior and measures 120 x 24mm.  The specimen measures 125mm superior to inferior x 115mm medial to lateral x 40mm superficial to deep.  The deep margin is inked black, lateral red and medial blue.  Specimen serially sliced from superior to inferior into twelve slices.  On sectioning a well circumscribed rounded tumour is identified.  The tumour measures 45mm superior to inferior x 60mm medial to lateral x 30mm superficial to deep.  The tumour appears completely excised and is 3mm from  the deep margin, 35mm from the superficial skin margin, 12mm from the lateral margin and 30mm from the medial margin. There is a nodular extension of tumour from the main mass; this is contiguous with the main tumor and measures 17 x 15 x 12mm.
Blocks: 1 and 2 - LS superior margin; 3 to 15 - full face slice six; 16 to 19 - RS nodular extension of tumour adjacent to tumour in slice eight; 20 to 23 - RS nodular extension of tumour in slice nine; 24 and 25 - LS inferior margin.  Please refer to attached block key diagram.  (TO: MS;MS/vo 19.4.67)


MICROSCOPIC (Reported by Dr N Dildine):
Sections show a circumscribed tumour with surrounding fibrofat.  The tumour is cellular.  It consists of a plump oval and spindle shaped cells with rather bland nuclei, pale or eosinophilic cytoplasm and poorly defined cell borders.  The cells have a haphazard arrangement.  There is patchy myxoid change with some associated microcyst formation, and elsewhere a more fibrous appearance with some hyalinisation.  Some ectatic vessels and other small staghorn-like vessels are noted.  There is patchy tumour necrosis and numerous mitoses are identified, numbering up to around 6 per 10 high power fields.  No lymphovascular or perineural invasion is identified.  A few thrombosed small vessels are noted in the tumour.
With immunostains, tumour cells show strong and diffuse positive staining for CD34.  There is patchy positive staining for bcl-2 and epithelial membrane antigen, and there is also some patchy positive staining for pancytokeratin.
Stains for mic-2 (CD99), desmin, smooth muscle actin, S100, and p63 are negative.
The proliferation index with a Ki-67 stain is around 7%.

The appearances are favoured to be those of a malignant solitary fibrous tumour.  Slides will be sent to MILTON ULLADULLA HOSPITAL Hospital for a STAT 6 immunostain and a supplementary report issued.  If the STAT 6 stain is negative then the tumour is best regarded as an undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (malignant fibrous histiocytoma).
Most of the tumour is surrounded by a fibrous capsule.  Excision of the tumour is complete.  The tumour is 1mm from the lateral margin of the closest point (block 17) and 4mm from the deep margin.  It is greater than 10mm from medial, superior, inferior and superficial margins.
Representative slides have also been viewed by Dr N Laughlin.


DIAGNOSIS:
Left thigh:  Spindle cell sarcoma, favour malignant solitary fibrous tumour, see text.


SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT (24.4.67):
With further immunostains, the tumour cells do not stain for ALK-1 or HMB-45.
The diagnosis is unchanged.


SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT (5.4.2067): Dr N Peabody
STAT6 immunohistochemistry (WALGETT HEALTH SERVICE) shows focal nuclear positivity, in keeping with the morphologic impression of a solitary fibrous tumour.
